head.title: How Yonkers Eliminated A $26 Million Budget Gap

hedline.hl1: How Yonkers Eliminated A $26 Million Budget Gap

abstract.p: Yonkers interim schools Superintendent Joseph Farmer says additional $10 million in aid from New York Gov George Pataki, coupled with retirement incentive for senior staff and cuts in programs, have ended current budget crisis; photo (M)

block.p: AFTER three months of hand wringing and the threat of layoffs because of a $26 million gap in this year's school budget, the Yonkers school system got a reprieve when Gov. George E. Pataki came to town with a $10 million check for the school district.
The money from Albany, coupled with a retirement incentive for senior staff and cuts in programs, ended the crisis for this year at least.

AFTER three months of hand wringing and the threat of layoffs because of a $26 million gap in this year's school budget, the Yonkers school system got a reprieve when Gov. George E. Pataki came to town with a $10 million check for the school district.
The money from Albany, coupled with a retirement incentive for senior staff and cuts in programs, ended the crisis for this year at least.

Still, alternative programs for middle- school and ninth-grade students will be lost, as will a program aimed at students with attention deficit disorder; 238 experienced teachers, administrators and staff are retiring early, and the opening of two renovated schools scheduled for this fall will be postponed.

Between those adjustments, which saved about $16 million, and the aid from the Governor, interim Superintendent Joseph Farmer said he was able to close the budget gap -- a feat that appeared nearly impossible two months ago when he took over the district.
All told, the final Yonkers budget for this year will be $343 million.
''I asked the school board to allow me a little more time before presenting my own doomsday budget to try and bring all the parties together, and they did that,'' Mr. Farmer said.

He then held several meetings with Mayor John D. Spencer, who had forced out the last superintendent, and lawyers from the N.A.A.C.P. to talk about settling the district's long-standing desegregation lawsuit -- an issue that proved to be the undoing of former Superintendent Andre J. Hornsby, who refused to settle.
Key to getting the money from Albany was this agreement, Mr. Farmer said. The $10 million check is actually an advance on whatever the final settlement amount will be.
Mr. Farmer also suggested that the school district's efforts this summer to trim its budget by $16 million registered as a sign of good faith with the governor.
''By us reducing the budget by $16 million, without help from the outside, showed that we were serious about this,'' he said. ''I think the key was this team effort of everybody.''
Even those who remain unhappy with the mayor and the ouster of Dr. Hornsby say they are relieved -- for the moment.

''The mayor took a gamble that we would get help from the state at the last minute, and the last horse came in,'' said Maria Chiulli, a school board member who has repeatedly denounced Mr. Spencer's involvement in school affairs. ''I'm very happy we got the money, but I look at it this way: I don't like the crisis situation we always seem to be in. As far as I'm concerned, we're already in a hole for next year.''

Mr. Farmer said the district's settlement funds -- whenever they come -- will be paid over a number of years, as opposed to arriving in one lump sum, to lend a measure of predictability and stability to school finances.
